revision.comment: migrating [[Wikipedia:Persondata|Persondata]] to Wikidata, [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/|please help]], see [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/challenge.php/article/Alexandre-Marie Quesnay de Beaurepaire|challenges for this article]]
revision.text:
'''Alexandre-Marie Quesnay de Beaurepaire''' (1755–1820<ref>{{cite journal|last=Roberts|first=John G|title=François Quesnay's Heir|jstor=4245161|work=The Virginia Magazine of History and Biography |volume=50 |issue=2 |date=April 1942 |pages=143–150|publisher=Virginia Historical Society}}</ref>) was the grandson of French philosopher and economist, [[François Quesnay]], and was among the idealistic French contingency who joined in the American struggle for independence during the late 18th century.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Duveen|first=Denis I.|author2=Herbert S. Klickstein|title=The Virginia Magazine of History and Biography|date=July 1955|volume= 63| issue = 3|pages= 280–285|jstor=4246133|publisher=Virginia Historical Society}}</ref>
De Beaurepaire is best known for occupying several positions: a captain in the Royal Guards of [[Louis XVI of France|Louis XVI]], French captain (with residence in Virginia) in the [[American Revolutionary War#Combatants before 1778#American armies and militias|American Revolutionary War Army]] (April 1777 – 1778) and co-patron, alongside Thomas Jefferson, of the short-lived first United States Academy of Science & Arts in Richmond, Virginia.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Roberts|first=John G.|title=An Exchange of Letters between Jefferson and Quesnay de Beaurepaire|jstor=4245160|work=The Virginia Magazine of History and Biography |volume=50 |issue=2 |date=April 1942 |pages=134–142|publisher=Virginia Historical Society}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Duveen & Klickstein|first=Denis I. and Herbert S|title=Alexandre-Marie Quesnay De Beaurepaire's: Mémoire et prospectus, concernant l'Académie des Sciences et Beaux Arts des Etats-Unis de l'Amérique, établie à Richemond, 1788|jstor=4246133|work=The Virginia Magazine of History and Biography |volume=63 |issue=3 |date=July 1955 |pages=280–285|publisher=Virginia Historical Society}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Shawen|first=Neil McDowell|title=Thomas Jefferson and a "National" University: The Hidden Agenda for Virginia|jstor=4248729|work=The Virginia Magazine of History and Biography |volume=92 |issue=3 |date=July 1984 |pages=309–335|publisher=Virginia Historical Society}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Gaines|first=Richard Heyward|title=Richmond's First Academy projected by M. QUESNAY DE BEAUREPAIRE|url=http://www.newrivernotes.com/va/richacad.htm|work=New River Notes|publisher=Jeffrey C. Weaver, Arlington, Virginia}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Davis|first=Richard B.|title=Jefferson as Collector of Virginiana|jstor=40371301|work=Studies in Bibliography|publisher=Bibliographical Society of the University of Virginia|pages=117–144}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Hale|first=George E.|title=National Academies and the Progress of Research|jstor=1640770|work=Science, New Series |volume=39 |issue=997 |date=February 1914 |pages=189–200|publisher=America Association for the Advancement of Science |doi=10.1126/science.39.997.189}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Paulston|first=Roland G|title=French Influence in American Institutions of Higher Learning, 1784–1825|jstor=367354|work=History of Education Quarterly |volume=8 |issue=2 |date=Summer 1968 |pages=229–245|publisher=History of Education Society |doi=10.2307/367354}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Cutting|first=Starr Willard|title=Modern Languages in the General Scheme of American Education|jstor=30167936|work=Monatshefte für deutsche Sprache und Pädagogik |volume=19 |issue=2 |date=February 1918 |pages=25–34 |publisher=University of Wisconsin Press}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Schinz|first=Albert|title=La librairie française en Amérique au temps de Washington|jstor=40518042|work=Revue d'Histoire littéraire de la France|publisher=Presses Universitaires de France|pages=568–584}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=An Early Chapter in American Art History|jstor=20561437|work=Art and Progress |volume=6 |issue=6 |date=April 1915 |page=208|publisher=The American Foundation of Arts}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Smith|first=Harlan I.|title=A Summary of Wisconsin Archeology|jstor=1627839|work=Science, New Series |volume=13 |issue=333 |date=May 1901 |pages=794–795|publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science |doi=10.1126/science.13.333.794-a}}</ref>
